channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Emperor Akihito of Japan Raises Possibility of Leaving Throne
item.description: Emperor Akihito, 82, spoke publicly for the first time about retiring, saying he feared it would become “more difficult” to fulfill his duties.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: 5 Things to Know About Japan’s Emperor and Imperial Family
item.media:description: Emperor Hirohito, the father of Emperor Akihito.
item.description: The oldest continuous monarchy in the world, extending back to 600 B.C., has had an unbroken hereditary line of 125 emperors.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: How an Iranian’s Spy Saga Ends, 6 Years Later: He’s Executed
item.media:description: The Iranian nuclear scientist Shahram Amiri, with his son, was welcomed back in Tehran in 2010.
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian/Polaris, for The New York Times
item.description: In 2010, Shahram Amiri, a scientist, claimed on YouTube that the C.I.A. had kidnapped him. A subsequent video changed the narrative. Missing his son, he returned to Iran and disappeared.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Security Force of 85,000 Fills Rio, Unsettling Rights Activists
item.media:description: Soldiers helped provide security at Olympic Park in Rio de Janeiro on Sunday.
item.description: Incidents, including a mugging of a security chief and an assault on a Portuguese official, are piling up, while the show of force has raised concerns about overly aggressive policing.
item.dc:creator: ANNA JEAN KAISER and ANDREW JACOBS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Landslides in Mexico Kill at Least 39 After Rains From Tropical Storm Earl
item.media:description: The town of Huauchinango, Mexico, was among those struck by landslides caused by the rains of Tropical Storm Earl.
item.description: Record-breaking rains in the eastern states of Puebla and Veracruz caused landslides heavy enough to bury entire homes, the government said.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Election Shows Many South Africans Losing Faith in ‘Pompous’ A.N.C.
item.media:description: Workers taking down African National Congress election campaign posters in Chantelle, South Africa.
item.description: Black, middle-class voters appeared more concerned with mundane matters like good governance and taxes than with the party’s heroic liberation past.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Erdogan Seizes Failed Coup in Turkey as a Chance to Supplant Ataturk
item.media:description: A flag with a picture of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey waved during the “democracy and martyrs rally” on Sunday in Istanbul. “This was the second war of independence,” one of Mr. Erdogan’s supporters said of the failed coup on July 15.
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is racing to banish the legacy of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk and establish himself and Islam as the most consequential factors in modern Turkish history.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Edward Daly, Bishop During the Troubles in Northern Ireland, Dies at 82
item.media:description: The retired bishop Edward Daly in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, in 2014. He died on Monday at the age of 82.
item.media:credit: Brian Lawless/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: As a priest and later as bishop, he argued relentlessly for peace during the three decades of sectarian violence.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: From Syrian Rubble to German Concert Halls With a Piano, a Mission and Survivor’s Guilt
item.media:description: On a street in Wiesbaden, Germany, a woman recognized Mr. Ahmad from one of his concerts.
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.description: In a nation torn between embracing and fearing the migrants who have arrived in the past year, Aeham Ahmad has set himself the task of putting a human face on his fellow arrivals.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: As Peace Talks in Yemen Crumble, Civilians End Up in Cross Hairs Again
item.media:description: The graves of Houthi militants in Sana, Yemen, on Sunday.
item.description: The Saudi-led coalition is accused of bombing nonmilitary targets, but a United Nations panel said the Houthi rebels had hidden weapons and fighters in residential areas.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Thailand’s Divisions on Display in Vote Approving New Constitution
item.media:description: Gen. Prayuth Chan-ocha, second from left, the prime minister of Thailand and leader of the junta, in Bangkok on Monday. Initial results showed most voters in the capital and central Thailand favored the proposed constitution, while majorities elsewhere opposed it.
item.description: The proposed charter, which gives the military a powerful role, won strong support in central Thailand but was opposed in the northeast and far south.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: National Council for Peace and Order (Thailand)

item.title: Whoops! When Museum Visitors Get Touchy-Feely With the Exhibits and Unleash Mayhem
item.media:description: The wall clock, by the artist James Borden.
item.description: Visitors have defaced, punctured or smashed artifacts, sculptures or paintings by accident or because of a misguided desire to “fix” things.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: Thousands in Eastern Chinese City Protest Nuclear Waste Project
item.media:description: Jean-Bernard Lévy, left, chief executive of the French power company EDF, with Qian Zhimin, center, president of the China National Nuclear Corporation, and Philippe Knoche, chief executive of Areva, in Paris last year.
item.description: Officials in Lianyungang emphasized that the plans for a fuel recycling plant had not been finalized, after large crowds demonstrated over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: 6 South Korean Lawmakers Accused of Taking China’s Side Against Antimissile System
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea accused the opponents of her decision to deploy the American military’s Terminal High-Altitude Area Defense system, or Thaad, of making “absurd arguments that jibe with North Korea’s.”
item.description: They pressed ahead with a Beijing trip, and the president criticized them for “sympathizing” with the Chinese over the American military’s Terminal High-Altitude Area Defense system.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Hospital Bombing in Pakistani City of Quetta Kills at Least 54
item.media:description: Mourners on Monday after the hospital attack in Quetta. The blast occurred shortly after the body of a prominent lawyer, killed by gunmen earlier in the day, had been transferred to the hospital.
item.description: The explosion, apparently caused by a suicide bomber, struck a hospital where lawyers had gathered to condemn the killing of a prominent colleague.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Sinosphere: Reconstructing Taoism’s Transformation in China
item.media:description: A Taoist nun at the Beichan Temple in Xining, in the Chinese province of Qinghai.
item.description: Terry F. Kleeman has published the first book in a Western language on the founding of Taoism as a formal religion, rooted in earlier philosophical texts.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Kenya Angers Taiwan by Deporting More Fraud Suspects to China
item.media:description: Suspects in court in Nairobi, Kenya, last week before their acquittals in a telephone fraud case. Forty of the defendants, five of them from Taiwan, have since been deported to mainland China.
item.description: Taiwan said the deportations of five of its people to the mainland, which followed similar ones in April, showed “contempt for human rights.”
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Ivo Pitanguy, Plastic Surgeon to the Stars and a Celebrity Himself, Dies at 93
item.media:description: Dr. Ivo Pitanguy carried the Olympic torch in Rio de Janeiro on Friday.
item.description: Dr. Pitanguy established himself in Brazil as one of the world’s most famous plastic surgeons, as much through his marketing savvy as through his surgical skills.
item.dc:creator: NATASHA SINGER

item.title: South Korean Missile Defense Deal Appears to Sour China’s Taste for K-Pop
item.media:description: The South Korean boy band EXO in 2013. Two of its scheduled concerts in Shanghai have been canceled.
item.media:credit: Starnews, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: In the wake of a Korean military agreement with the United States, several events in China featuring the South’s music and television stars have been canceled.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Rebel Offensive in Syria Challenges Government Siege of Aleppo
item.media:description: Fighters and civilians on Saturday celebrating news of a rebel offensive against the siege of Aleppo, Syria, by forces loyal to the government.
item.description: A coalition including the jihadist group formerly known as the Nusra Front seized military facilities and tentatively opened a road into rebel-held districts.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and MAHER SAMAAN

item.title: A ‘Water Bomb’ of a Storm Kills 21 in Macedonia’s Capital, Skopje
item.media:description: People fled their flooded homes Sunday in the village of Stajkovci, near Skopje, Macedonia.
item.description: At least 77 people were injured in a rainstorm that surprised even Macedonia’s top weather authorities with its ferocity.
item.dc:creator: ALEKSANDAR DIMISHKOVSKI

item.title: Narendra Modi, India’s Leader, Condemns Vigilante Cow Protection Groups
item.media:description: A temple in Pushkar, India. Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Saturday distanced himself from right-wing cow protection groups that have attacked Muslims and others.
item.description: The groups have attacked Muslims and, more recently, low-caste Hindus, under the guise of protecting animals sacred to Hindus.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Islamic State Claims Responsibility for Belgium Machete Attack
item.description: The group issued a statement saying the attacker, who wounded two police officers before being fatally shot, was its “soldier.”
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Voters in Thailand Endorse Military’s Proposed Constitution
item.description: The document, which won overwhelming approval Sunday, would be the country’s 20th Constitution in 84 years. It aims to reduce the power of political parties and extend the influence of the military.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte, Philippine President, Links 150 Public Servants to Drugs
item.media:description: Cipriano Violago Jr., the mayor of San Rafael, in Bulacan Province, was one of dozens of officials that President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines publicly linked to the illegal drug trade on Sunday. He has denied the allegations.
item.description: He named judges, mayors, lawmakers, military personnel and police officers and gave them 24 hours to surrender for investigation or be “hunted” down.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Deliveroo, an On-Demand Food Delivery Service, Raises $275 Million
item.media:description: The Deliveroo offices in central London. The company operates in 12 countries, mostly in Europe.
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.description: The London-based start-up plans to use the money to expand its global footprint as the companies like Uber have started to offer rival services.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: What in the World: Put One Foot Wrong in This Town and You’ve Left the Country
item.description: Borders dating to the 12th century carve Baarle into a crazy patchwork, splitting sidewalks, shops and houses between Belgium and the Netherlands.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: What in the World: The Face of Taiwan’s Past Is Slowly Fading From View
item.media:description: More than 200 statues of Chiang Kai-shek, the Chinese Nationalist leader who died in 1975, have been moved to a park near his mausoleum in Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan.
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.description: As the island has democratized, statues and busts of Chiang Kai-shek, the longtime president of the Republic of China, are gradually being either removed or relocated.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: What in the World: British Royal History, and Intrigue, in a Quaint German Town
item.media:description: The German town of Celle is an ancestral home of Britain’s royal family, the Windsors.
item.description: Celle, Germany, has played host to British royals on several occasions because of its role as an ancestral home of the House of Windsor.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Editorial: Many Countries Will Need Help Adapting to Climate Change
item.description: Rich nations need to make good on their pledges, particularly to low-lying island nations whose very existence is threatened.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: America’s Dangerous ‘Putin Panic’
item.media:description: A delegate’s sign at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia last month.
item.description: Paranoia about Russian meddling only makes Moscow stronger.
item.dc:creator: IVAN KRASTEV

item.title: Editorial: Show Trials in China
item.description: The campaign against legal activists is part of a pattern that’s dismally familiar in the annals of authoritarian governments.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenager’s Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantánamo
item.media:description: Ahmed Abdul Qader, a former Guantánamo Bay detainee, at Freedom Square in Tallinn, Estonia, in May.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
